utterances.transcript: čuu, humwic̓aʔaqƛs ʔuuqḥɬi qʷisḥitiič kumtkʷačiʔat quʔušin kukʷinksi ʔan c̓iic̓ikiikit naʔaaʔat.
utterances.translation: Now then, I will tell you a story about how Raven got crooked fingers as a result of imitating what he heard.
He would never stop looking for something to eat.

utterances.transcript: misp̓uuqsčiʔaƛquuč haʔum yee, ʔucačiƛ ʔusumḥi haw̓ik. ʔusumḥi ḥanaaqƛ.
utterances.translation: He would sense the smell of food and go any distance (to get food), because he was such a glutton and because he was so greedy.

utterances.transcript: čuu, ʔucaḥtačiʔaƛwaʔiš yaacpanač hiy̓atḥʔitq čumsm̓iit, naʔaap̓uqsčiƛ ʔan wiqaaʔak suuḥaa.
utterances.translation: Now, he went out for a walk heading to the place where Son of Bear lived, and he smelled that Bear was cooking salmon.
Well! I was walking around, and I thought to myself “I’m going to pay you all a visit,” [said Raven].
“Come in, come in,” they (Bear and his wife) told him, inviting him into the house.
Then, he entered the house.

utterances.transcript: čaʔaaɬči, suuḥn̓aaḥ waaʔaƛ ɬuucmaʔisuk, hiniiʔas čumsm̓iit.
utterances.translation: “Go and gt some salmon,” Bear’s little wife told him [her husband]. And Bear went out.

utterances.transcript: ʔucačiƛ c̓aʔakʔi. suuḥiip, ʕačšiƛ suuḥaa. mačinƛ.
utterances.translation: He went to the river. He grabbed salmon and went back in the house.

utterances.transcript: nay̓iik ʔuutaqšiƛ ɬuucmaʔi, čums ɬuucmaak, kuučiɬšiƛ ƛ̓apč̓iitap, siqay̓ap.
utterances.translation: Right away Bear’s wife filleted and barbecued fish on the ground, cooked it.
Raven was watching what Bear was doing. He was watching carefully.
He (Bear) closed his eyes partially and said [to his wife], “Get me a clam shell.”
[Bear’s wife] followed what he (Bear) told her to do and went out to get it.
She came back with a clam shell.
Son of Raven watched what he (Bear) was doing.
He (Bear) went close to the fire on the floor.
He (Bear) put out his hands towards the fire.
He set down the clam shell there [to collect oil by melting the fat on his hands].
He (Raven) watched what he did.
Oil started dripping from Bear’s hands.
After a little while the shells got full [with oil].
Now, they put it (the food) in front of Raven.
They fed him (Raven).
He got greedy.

utterances.transcript: naʔukšiʔaƛ. haʔukšiʔaƛ ʔuʔuiic̓at suuḥaa ƛaqmis ʔuunaqa.
utterances.translation: He started eating. He started eating salmon with oil.
He got full and went to sleep.
Then he got up.

utterances.transcript: hee haaw̓awiiqšʔaƛs suutiɬ. haw̓aasʔum ʔam̓ii waaʔaƛ quʔušinm̓it.
utterances.translation: “Well, I will invite you [to my place for food]. You come and eat [at my place] tomorrow,” said Raven.
“Oh, I will accept the invitation,” said Bear.

utterances.transcript: hišukʷaƛ̓at huḥtak̓at qʷaaʔiitq quʔušinm̓it, ʔayisaʕaqƛ, c̓iic̓ikiik qʷaan̓ak̓uuḥʔitq.
utterances.translation: People all knew how Raven was: he was cunning and imitated whatever he saw.
“I will go along with your offer,” [Bear accepted the invitation].
Bear went to Raven’s place.
The other people watched him.
They knew he was going to trick him (Bear).
“Come in and sit down,” [Raven] said to [Bear].
Bear went in.
“OK, go find something to eat,” [Raven said to his wife].
He never had food for his wife. He was lazy.
He took [from someone else] and toasted dried salmon.
“Get me clam shells,” he said.
She (Raven’s wife) didn’t ask what he needed it for.
She obeyed him. She always listens to him.
She brought clam shells to her husband.
Now, he (Raven) went close to the fire.
He set the shells down.
“Look! He is going to imitate as usual,” the spectators said.
He put out his hands towards the fire.
The people watched what was happening to his hands.
The fire started to curl up his fingers because there was no oil in his hands.
His fingers got all curled up because he always imitated other people.
That is how he got crooked fingers.
